hints_html:
First isolate for y.

Find the points of intersection of the ellipse and the x-axis.

Note that by symmetry we need to only consider the positive square root and double the resulting value.

Either interpret this result as an area or try the trig substitution \(x = \sin(\theta)\)
hints_latex: Find the points of intersection of the ellipse and the \emph{x}-axis.

Note that by symmetry we need to only consider the positive square root
and double the resulting value.

Either interpret this result as an area or try the trig substitution
$x = \sin(\theta)$
hints_raw:
First isolate for ''y''.
Find the points of intersection of the ellipse and the ''x''-axis.
Note that by symmetry we need to only consider the positive square root and double the resulting value.
Either interpret this result as an area or try the trig substitution <math> x = \sin(\theta) </math>
question: 7 (a)
sols_html:
We proceed as in the hints. First, we isolate for y to see that

\(y^{2} = b^{2} - \frac{b^{2}x^{2}}{a^{2}} = \frac{b^{2}}{a^{2}} \left(a^{2} - x^{2} \right)\)

Taking the square roots yields

\(y = \pm \frac{b}{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}\)

Now, we want to know the aera fo the ellipse. First, we set \(y=0\) to find the points of intersection with the x-axis. This gives

\(\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}} - 0 = 1\)

So \(x = \pm a\). Thus, we wish to integrate

\(y = \pm \frac{b}{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}\)

from \(-a\) to \(a\). By symmetry, we need only to integrate the positive function above and then double our resulting value (pictorially, the ellipse has a symmetry that is reflection about the x-axis. So to get the full area, compute half of it then double your result). Thus, we have that

\(A = 2\int_{-a}^{a}\frac{b}{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}\, dx = \frac{2b}{a}\int_{-a}^{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}\, dx\)

This last integral can be interpreted as the area of a half circle of radius \(a\). This has area \(\displaystyle \frac{\pi a^2}{2}\). Thus, our area is

\(A = \frac{2b}{a}\int_{-a}^{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}\, dx = \frac{2b}{a} \cdot \frac{\pi a^2}{2} = \pi ab\)

completing the question.

We proceed as in solution one until the line

\(A = \frac{2b}{a}\int_{-a}^{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}} \, dx\)

Now we do a trig substitution. Let \(x = a\sin \theta\) so that \(dx = a\cos \theta d\theta\). Changing the bounds, we see that \(a = a\sin(\theta)\) so \(\theta = \tfrac{\pi}{2}\) and \(-a = a\sin(\theta)\) so \(\theta = -\tfrac{\pi}{2}\). Then the above becomes

\[\begin{aligned} A &= \frac{2b}{a}\int_{-a}^{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}} \, dx\\ &= \frac{2b}{a}\int_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}} \sqrt{a^{2}-a^{2} \sin^{2}\theta}a\cos \theta \,d\theta\\ &= 2ab\int_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}} \cos^{2} \theta \,d\theta\end{aligned}\]

Now we use the double angle formula

\(\cos^{2}(\theta) = \frac{1+\cos(2\theta)}{2}\)

to see that

\[\begin{aligned} A&= 2ab\int_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}\cos^{2}(\theta) \, d\theta \\ &= 2ab\int_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}\frac{1+\cos(2\theta)}{2} \, d\theta \\ &= \left.ab \theta\right|_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}} + ab\int_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}\cos(2\theta) \, d\theta \\ &= \frac{\pi ab}{2} + \frac{\pi ab}{2}+ \left.\frac{ab}{2} \sin(2\theta)\right|_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}\\ &= \pi ab + \frac{ab}{2} (\sin(\pi) - \sin(-\pi))\\ &= \pi ab\end{aligned}\]

completing the question.
sols_latex:
We proceed as in the hints. First, we isolate for \emph{y} to see that

$y^{2} = b^{2} - \frac{b^{2}x^{2}}{a^{2}} = \frac{b^{2}}{a^{2}} \left(a^{2} - x^{2} \right)$

Taking the square roots yields

$y = \pm \frac{b}{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}$

Now, we want to know the aera fo the ellipse. First, we set $y=0$ to
find the points of intersection with the \emph{x}-axis. This gives

$\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}} - 0 = 1$

So $x = \pm a$. Thus, we wish to integrate

$y = \pm \frac{b}{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}$

from $-a$ to $a$. By symmetry, we need only to integrate the positive
function above and then double our resulting value (pictorially, the
ellipse has a symmetry that is reflection about the \emph{x}-axis. So to
get the full area, compute half of it then double your result). Thus, we
have that

$A = 2\int_{-a}^{a}\frac{b}{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}\, dx = \frac{2b}{a}\int_{-a}^{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}\, dx$

This last integral can be interpreted as the area of a half circle of
radius $a$. This has area $\displaystyle \frac{\pi a^2}{2}$. Thus, our
area is

$A = \frac{2b}{a}\int_{-a}^{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}\, dx = \frac{2b}{a} \cdot \frac{\pi a^2}{2} = \pi ab$

completing the question.

We proceed as in solution one until the line

$A = \frac{2b}{a}\int_{-a}^{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}} \, dx$

Now we do a trig substitution. Let $x = a\sin \theta$ so that
$dx = a\cos \theta d\theta$. Changing the bounds, we see that
$a = a\sin(\theta)$ so $\theta = \tfrac{\pi}{2}$ and
$-a = a\sin(\theta)$ so $\theta = -\tfrac{\pi}{2}$. Then the above
becomes

\begin{align*}
A &= \frac{2b}{a}\int_{-a}^{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}} \, dx\\
&= \frac{2b}{a}\int_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}} \sqrt{a^{2}-a^{2} \sin^{2}\theta}a\cos \theta \,d\theta\\
&= 2ab\int_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}} \cos^{2} \theta \,d\theta
\end{align*}

Now we use the double angle formula

$\cos^{2}(\theta) = \frac{1+\cos(2\theta)}{2}$

to see that

\begin{align*}
A&= 2ab\int_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}\cos^{2}(\theta) \, d\theta \\
&= 2ab\int_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}\frac{1+\cos(2\theta)}{2} \, d\theta \\
&= \left.ab \theta\right|_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}} +  ab\int_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}\cos(2\theta) \, d\theta \\
&= \frac{\pi ab}{2} + \frac{\pi ab}{2}+ \left.\frac{ab}{2} \sin(2\theta)\right|_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}\\
&= \pi ab  +  \frac{ab}{2} (\sin(\pi) - \sin(-\pi))\\
&= \pi ab
\end{align*}

completing the question.
sols_raw:
We proceed as in the hints. First, we isolate for ''y'' to see that

<math>
y^{2} = b^{2} - \frac{b^{2}x^{2}}{a^{2}} = \frac{b^{2}}{a^{2}} \left(a^{2} - x^{2} \right)
</math>

Taking the square roots yields

<math>
y = \pm \frac{b}{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}
</math>

Now, we want to know the aera fo the ellipse. First, we set <math> y=0 </math> to find the points of intersection with the ''x''-axis. This gives

<math>
\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}} - 0 = 1
</math>

So <math> x = \pm a </math>. Thus, we wish to integrate

<math>
y = \pm \frac{b}{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}
</math>

from <math> -a </math> to <math> a </math>. By symmetry, we need only to integrate the positive function above and then double our resulting value (pictorially, the ellipse has a symmetry that is reflection about the ''x''-axis. So to get the full area, compute half of it then double your result). Thus, we have that

<math> 
A = 2\int_{-a}^{a}\frac{b}{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}\, dx = \frac{2b}{a}\int_{-a}^{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}\, dx
</math>

This last integral can be interpreted as the area of a half circle of radius <math> a </math>. This has area <math> \displaystyle \frac{\pi a^2}{2} </math>. Thus, our area is

<math> 
A = \frac{2b}{a}\int_{-a}^{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}\, dx = \frac{2b}{a} \cdot \frac{\pi a^2}{2} = \pi ab
</math>

completing the question.
We proceed as in solution one until the line

<math> 
A = \frac{2b}{a}\int_{-a}^{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}} \, dx
</math>

Now we do a trig substitution. Let <math> x = a\sin \theta  </math> so that <math> dx = a\cos \theta d\theta </math>. Changing the bounds, we see that <math> a = a\sin(\theta) </math> so <math> \theta = \tfrac{\pi}{2} </math> and  <math> -a = a\sin(\theta) </math> so <math> \theta = -\tfrac{\pi}{2} </math>. Then the above becomes

<math> 
\begin{align}
A &= \frac{2b}{a}\int_{-a}^{a} \sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}} \, dx\\
&= \frac{2b}{a}\int_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}} \sqrt{a^{2}-a^{2} \sin^{2}\theta}a\cos \theta \,d\theta\\
&= 2ab\int_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}} \cos^{2} \theta \,d\theta
\end{align}
</math>

Now we use the double angle formula

<math>
\cos^{2}(\theta) = \frac{1+\cos(2\theta)}{2}
</math>

to see that

<math>
\begin{align}
A&= 2ab\int_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}\cos^{2}(\theta) \, d\theta \\
&= 2ab\int_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}\frac{1+\cos(2\theta)}{2} \, d\theta \\
&= \left. ab \theta\right|_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}} +  ab\int_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}\cos(2\theta) \, d\theta \\
&= \frac{\pi ab}{2} + \frac{\pi ab}{2}+ \left.\frac{ab}{2} \sin(2\theta)\right|_{-\tfrac{\pi}{2}}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}\\
&= \pi ab  +  \frac{ab}{2} (\sin(\pi) - \sin(-\pi))\\
&= \pi ab
\end{align}
</math>


completing the question.
statement_html:
Show that the area of the region inside the ellipse

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{x^2}{a^2} + \frac{y^2}{b^2} = 1,\end{aligned}\]

where a and b are positive constants, equals \(\displaystyle \pi ab.\)
statement_raw:
Show that the area of the region inside the ellipse

:<math>
\frac{x^2}{a^2} + \frac{y^2}{b^2} = 1,
</math>

where ''a'' and ''b'' are positive constants, equals <math>\displaystyle \pi ab.</math>
